results.title: Crossenvale stories : Digital Storytelling project
results.brief_description: Eight residents of the Crossendale estate in Echuca in Northern Victoria share their personal stories as part of a Digital Storytelling workshop. While the subjects vary, the topic is mostly centred around the things that lie closest to the participants’ hearts.
results.description: Eight residents of the Crossendale estate in Echuca in Northern Victoria share their personal stories as part of a Digital Storytelling workshop. While the subjects vary, the topic is mostly centred around the things that lie closest to the participants’ hearts.

results.title: Crossbanding and jointing veneers
results.creator_credit: Topical Film Company and K. Baron Hartley
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Basic woodwork”.
Both sides of the wood are veneered to prevent warping. The method of making this is demonstrated through an example of a door made of laminated wood. It is explained how to veneer the face of the door to match the edges and when a piece of veneer is not wide enough to cover a surface, how a joint must be made.

results.title: Cross your heart and hope to live
results.creator_credit: Bert Christensen and Danish Heart Foundation
results.brief_description: Looks at the rising incidence of heart disease in Western society. Of babies born with perfect arteries, by the age of 15 virtually everybody has ruined them to some extent. Points out that the “good life” is responsible - smoking, lack of physical activity, excess fatty substances in the blood, high blood pressure and overweight are to blame. Suggestions are made for overcoming the problem.

results.title: Cross of iron
results.creator_credit: Rapid Film GmbH, Alex Winitsky, Arlene Sellers and Sam Peckinpah
results.brief_description: 1943 : the German Army is retreating, pounded on all sides by the Russian onslaught. The only men who survive are those who revel in war and destruction. Men like Sargeant Steiner (James Coburn). And men who won’t risk their necks for anything. Men like Captain Stransky (Maximilian Schell). Stransky is new to the ugliness of front-line battles, but determined to win himself some glory before he returns home. The one thing he wants above all is the supreme symbol of bravery - the Iron Cross. And he wants Steiner to win it for him - and get blown apart while doing so. Stranky’s determination to obtain that coveted emblem of bravery at whatever cost is the background to Sam Peckinpah’s gripping story of men living at extremes and fighting for their lives. Based on the novel by Willi Heinrich.

results.title: Cross currents (A)
results.creator_credit: Erika Jakubassa, Georgia Allen and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
This video examines the problems encountered by Aborigines and overseas born Australians when dealing with the health care system. Health care professionals discuss the importance of providing interpreting services, of the need for cross-cultural communication training, and the need for health services to encourage the employment of staff from a variety of cultural backgrounds. The video dramatises some of the drastic consequences of doctors and health professionals not communicating effectively with patients from other cultural backgrounds.

results.title: Cross currents
results.brief_description:
An image from a newspaper featuring Eastern European women being forced into prostitution and slavery at the end of the Yugoslav-Serbo-Croatian war, sets the scene for the Cross Currents exhibition. Presented in two sections, interactive video and linear video, as well as being in English and German language, events are recreated leading up to a police raid on a sex slave hotel in Berlin. The raid is recreated from the opposing points of view of an enslaved Croatian sex worker and her Serbian bodyguard.

Cross Currents premiered at ZKM, Centre for Art and Media, Karlsruhe, Germany in 1999.

results.title: Cross cultural approach to acquisition of sex roles and social standards (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Jerome Kagan, Glen Howard, Harper & Row and Bay State Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Development of the Child”.
The culturally diverse settings of Guatemala, Kenya and Japan focus on the basic mechanisms by which social standards and sex role orientations are acquired. Children are shown learning by the mechanisms of observation, imitation, praise and punishment.

results.title: Cross-section of Central America: Guatemala
results.creator_credit: Leroy Phelps and Louis de Rochemont Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Earth and it’s peoples”.
Shows the life-style and occupations of the Indian people of Guatemala, including the felling of mahogany trees in the forests and farming on the high plateaux. Starting from the east in the Peten lowlands the film proceeds north-westwards across Central America, focusing attention on features which are typical of the geography of the Peten lowlands, the central highlands, and the Pacific coastlands. It exemplifies changes in modes of life with increased altitude within this tropical area, and illustrates some of the influences of the civilization of the Mayas and of Spanish colonial rule.
